title: How to Make an Egg Ring when Camping

steps.headline: Cut out the center of a piece of bread.
steps.description: Cut in a roughly circular shape to fit the egg. Leave the square crust intact.

steps.headline: Toast or eat the bread taken from the middle.
steps.description: Alternatively, you can fry the center part after the eggs are done, for a tasty and crunchy bread treat.

steps.headline: Place the crust circle/square in the frying pan or other cooking container.
steps.description: Crack each egg into the center of each crust ring.

steps.headline: Cook as usual.
steps.description: The egg will move out to the edge of the crust and stay there.

steps.headline: Remove once cooked.
steps.description: Here you have two choices. The egg can be removed from the crust and eaten alone, or you can eat both the fried crust with the egg attached (a double treat! ).

methods.name: Onion or bell pepper egg ring

steps.headline: Slice the onion or bell pepper across the width.
If using an onion, pop out all of the inner rings.
steps.description: Use the larger outer rings for the egg ring.

steps.headline: If using a bell pepper, pull out any center pith and seeds.
Place the vegetable circles into the frying pan or skillet being used for cooking on the campfire or camp stove.
Crack the egg into the middle of the vegetable ring.
steps.description: Cook until the egg is at the firmness of your liking.

steps.headline: Remove.
steps.description: You can eat the vegetable ring too, or remove it as preferred.
